impulse.translation[0].definitions[0].de: a sudden strong desire to do something without thinking about whether it is a sensible thing to do
impulse.translation[0].definitions[0].no: impulse buying/shopping (=when you buy things that you had not planned to buy)
impulse.translation[0].definitions[0].ex: Marge’s first impulse was to run.
Gerry couldn’t resist the impulse to kiss her.
On impulse, I picked up the phone and rang her.
Most beginners buy plants on impulse and then hope for the best.
impulse.translation[0].definitions[1].de: a short electrical signal that travels in one direction along a nerve or wire
impulse.translation[0].definitions[1].ex: The eye converts light signals to nerve impulses.
impulse.translation[0].definitions[2].de: a reason or aim that causes a particular kind of activity or behaviour
impulse.translation[0].definitions[2].ex: It is the passions which provide the main impulse of music.
impulse.translation[0].note_box[0].headi: – Meaning 1 : a sudden strong desire to do something without thinking about whether it is a sensible thing to do
impulse.translation[0].note_box[0].secti: He had a strong impulse to punch Stan in the face.
irresistible
I felt an irresistible impulse to giggle.
a sudden impulse
She felt a sudden impulse to play some music.
somebody's first/initial impulse
Her first impulse was to turn and walk away.
a natural impulse
My natural impulse was to shout for help.
have/feel an impulse to
Rosa had an impulse to tell Henry the truth.
resist/control an impulse
Derek resisted the impulse to eat any more cake.
act on an impulse
Acting on an impulse, he decided to visit his sister.
obey an impulse
Yielding to an impulse, she called him on her mobile phone.
impulse + NOUN
an impulse buy
She admitted that the necklace had been an impulse buy.
do something on impulse
James bought her some flowers on impulse.
